questions.text: An article was published about the middle ear. 3 rd -year medical students are given the assignment to read it thoroughly after the very next day. A question was displayed in class multimedia, which of the following statements is correct about the perilymph? Perilymph fills the Scala vestibuli & Scala media Perilymph resembles extracellular fluid and is rich in Na + ions. Perilymph - High sodium & Low potassium Perilymph - Low sodium & High potassium
questions.explanation:
Aspect Description
Definition Perilymph is a fluid found in the inner ear, specifically in the bony labyrinth, surrounding the membranous labyrinth.
Location It fills the space between the bony labyrinth and the membranous labyrinth in the inner ear.
Composition - Resembles extracellular fluid
  - High sodium (Na+) levels
  - Low potassium (K+) levels
Origin Perilymph is derived from cerebrospinal fluid, and its composition is similar to CSF.
Function - Helps in sound conduction and balance
  - Acts as a medium for transmitting sound vibrations from the middle ear to the cochlea.
  - Maintains the proper ionic environment necessary for the function of sensory cells in the inner ear.
Relationship with Endolymph The composition of perilymph differs from that of endolymph, which is the fluid found within the membranous labyrinth. Endolymph has low sodium and high potassium levels.
Clinical Relevance Disturbances in perilymph composition or pressure can lead to inner ear disorders such as Meniere's disease and perilymphatic fistulas.

Choice A Neuroectoderm All neurons of CNS, neurohypophysis, retina, pineal gland, preganglionic autonomic fibers, astrocytes, ependymal cells, and the choroid plexus
Choice B Surface ectoderm Skin and its appendages, the nasal and oral epithelium, the anal epithelium to the dentate line, the lens and cornea
Choice D Mesoderm Muscles, bones, blood, genital tissues, the dermis and most organ systems
Choice E Notochord Completely regresses in humans, major vestige is nulceus pulposus in intervertebral discs

He works out 5 times a week and has an active lifestyle. On physical examination there are several papules on his lips. This patient also has digital clubbing. Rest physical examination is normal. Correct sequence in Gram staining?

options.label: A
options.text: Methyl violet → Iodine → Acetone → Carbol fuchsin

options.label: B
options.text: Carbol fuchsin → Iodine → Acetone → Methyl violet

options.label: C
options.text: Methyl violet → Acetone → Iodine → Carbol fuchsin

options.label: D
options.text: Methyl violet → Carbol fuchsin → Acetone → Iodine

questions.correct_answer: A. Methyl violet → Iodine → Acetone → Carbol fuchsin
questions.explanation:
Option a, b, c, d

1. Gram stain: It was devised by Christian Gram, a Danish microbiologist, in 1884, as a convenient method for classifying bacteria. The Gram staining method essentially consists of four steps:

  • (i) Primary staining with basic dyes, such as methyl violet, crystal violet, etc.
  • (ii) Application of mordant in the form of dilute solution of iodine.
  • (iii) Decolorization with ethanol, acetone, or aniline.
  • (iv) Counterstaining with acidic dyes, such as carbol fuchsin, safranine, or neutral red.

2. Gram-positive bacteria are those that resist decolorization and retain the primary dye-iodine complex, appearing violet. They have a relatively thick amorphous wall and more acidic protoplasm which are believed to retain the basic violet dye and iodine complex within the cell.

3. Gram-negative bacteria are decolorized by organic solvents and take counterstain, appearing pink. The decolorizing agent, such as acetone or ethanol, used during staining disrupts this membran-ous envelope, and the dye and iodine complex is washed out of Gram-negative bacteria.

questions.explanation:
Causes of Cerebrovascular Accidents
Ischemic (85%)
Hemorrhage (15%)

→ Embolic (75%)

→ Thrombotic (25%)

→ Parenchymal (10%)

→ Subarachnoid (1-2%)

→ Epidural (<1%)

→ Subdural (<1%)

Intracerebral (Parenchymal) Hemorrhage Subarachnoid Hemorrhage

→ MC type of intracranial hemorrhage

→ MC cause is hypertension, causing rupture of small perforating arteries or arterioles

→ MC site: Basal ganglia (Putamen)

→ 2nd MC cause of intracranial hemorrhage

→ MC cause : Trauma> Spontaneuos rupture of Berry aneurysm

→ MC site of Berry aneurysm is anterior circulation of “circle of willis”
